topIssues.title: feat: Add JSON API endpoints for summaries
topIssues.author: madjin
topIssues.body:
## Summary

Extend the static JSON API to include summary endpoints alongside the existing leaderboard endpoints.

## Current State

We have leaderboard API endpoints working:
- `/data/api/leaderboard-monthly.json`
- `/data/api/leaderboard-weekly.json`
- `/data/api/leaderboard-lifetime.json`

## Proposed Summary API Endpoints

Export all historical summaries as structured JSON:

```
/data/api/summaries/overall/{interval}/{date}.json
/data/api/summaries/repos/{owner}/{repo}/{interval}/{date}.json
/data/api/summaries/contributors/{username}/{interval}/{date}.json
```

### Response Structure

```typescript
interface SummaryAPIResponse {
  version: "1.0";
  type: "overall" | "repository" | "contributor";
  interval: "day" | "week" | "month";
  date: string;           // YYYY-MM-DD
  generatedAt: string;    // ISO timestamp
  content: string;        // Markdown content
}
```

## Implementation Plan

### Shared Infrastructure
Create `src/lib/pipelines/export/apiHelpers.ts` with:
- `APIResponseBase` interface (version, generatedAt)
- `writeAPIResponse()` function
- `calculateDateRange()` (extract from leaderboard)

### Files to Create/Modify
1. `src/lib/pipelines/export/apiHelpers.ts` - New shared utilities
2. `src/lib/pipelines/export/exportLeaderboardAPI.ts` - Simplify (remove pagination, keep totalUsers)
3. `src/lib/pipelines/export/exportSummaryAPI.ts` - New file
4. `cli/analyze-pipeline.ts` - Add `export-summaries` command
5. `.github/workflows/deploy.yml` - Add export step
6. `README.md` - Document all API endpoints

## Additional Changes

- **Simplify leaderboard API**: Remove pagination object, keep just `totalUsers` (pagination doesn't make sense for static JSON files)

## Questions to Discuss

- Should we include index files listing all available summaries?
- Any additional metadata to include in the response?
- Rate of export - all summaries on every deploy, or incremental?

---

topIssues.title: Next.js upgrade blocked: RSC serialization error in StatCardsDisplay
topIssues.author: madjin
topIssues.body:
## Problem

Upgrading Next.js from 15.2.6 to 15.4.10+ (or 16.x) causes build failures with:

```
Error: Functions cannot be passed directly to Client Components unless you explicitly expose it by marking it with "use server". Or maybe you meant to call this function rather than return it.
  {$$typeof: ..., render: function, displayName: ...}
```

Affected route: `/summary/[interval]/[[...date]]/page`

## Root Cause

`StatCardsDisplay` is an async server component that passes pre-rendered JSX elements to `StatCard` (client component) via the `modalContent` prop:

```tsx
// src/app/summary/[interval]/[[...date]]/components/StatCardsDisplay.tsx
<StatCard
  modalContent={<ContributorsListModalContent contributors={metrics.topContributors} />}
>
```

React elements contain render functions which aren't serializable across the RSC boundary. This worked in 15.2.6 but stricter versions catch this violation.

## Solutions

From [Next.js discussions](https://github.com/vercel/next.js/discussions/49625):

1. **Make StatCardsDisplay a client component** - Add `"use client"` directive
2. **Pass data instead of JSX** - Pass serializable props, render modal content inside client component
3. **Use composition pattern** - Use `children` prop which has special RSC handling

Recommended approach: Option 2 - refactor `StatCard` to accept a `modalContentType` + `modalData` props instead of pre-rendered JSX.

## Files to Modify

- `src/components/stat-card.tsx` - Already has `"use client"`, needs prop refactor
- `src/app/summary/[interval]/[[...date]]/components/StatCardsDisplay.tsx` - Pass data not JSX
- Modal content components may need to move inside stat-card or be lazy-imported

## Current Workaround

Stay on Next.js 15.2.6 until this refactor is complete.

## References

- [Next.js Discussion #49625](https://github.com/vercel/next.js/discussions/49625)
- [Next.js Issue #42408](https://github.com/vercel/next.js/issues/42408)
- [How to Fix Guide](https://www.timsanteford.com/posts/how-to-fix-functions-cannot-be-passed-directly-to-client-components-error-in-next-js/)

## Related PRs

- PR #175 - RSS feed fix (separate issue)

topIssues.title: chore: Remove 10 unused dependencies
topIssues.author: madjin
topIssues.body:
## Summary

During a dependency audit, 10 packages were identified as unused and can be safely removed to reduce bundle size and maintenance burden.

## Unused Dependencies

| Package | Reason Unused |
|---------|---------------|
| `@anthropic-ai/sdk` | AI summaries use OpenRouter API via `fetch()`, not this SDK |
| `openai` | Same - OpenRouter handles all AI calls, SDK not imported |
| `boxen` | Not imported anywhere in codebase |
| `figlet` | Not imported anywhere in codebase |
| `fuzzysort` | Not imported anywhere in codebase |
| `gradient-string` | Not imported anywhere in codebase |
| `gray-matter` | Not imported anywhere in codebase |
| `unified` | Not imported; `react-markdown` handles remark plugins internally |
| `remark-frontmatter` | Not imported anywhere in codebase |
| `remark-parse` | Not imported anywhere in codebase |

## Verification Method

Each package was checked for:
- Direct imports (`import from 'package'`)
- Require statements
- Usage in config files (next.config, tailwind.config, postcss.config, etc.)
- Peer dependency requirements from other packages

## Notes

- The AI summary system (`src/lib/pipelines/summarize/callAIService.ts`) uses raw `fetch()` to call OpenRouter's API endpoint, making both `openai` and `@anthropic-ai/sdk` unnecessary
- `task-master-ai` (devDependency) bundles its own dependencies and uses `@ai-sdk/anthropic` (Vercel AI SDK), not `@anthropic-ai/sdk`
- `boxen`, `figlet`, `gradient-string`, `fuzzysort`, `gray-matter` appear to be remnants from earlier development

## Recommended Action

Remove these from `package.json` dependencies:
```bash
bun remove @anthropic-ai/sdk openai boxen figlet fuzzysort gradient-string gray-matter unified remark-frontmatter remark-parse
```

This should reduce install size and simplify the dependency tree.

topIssues.title: Enhancement: Adaptive Rate Limiting for 60% Faster Multi-Repo Ingestion
topIssues.author: madjin
topIssues.body:
## Problem: Sequential Processing is Too Slow for Multi-Repo Pipelines

### Current Bottleneck

The current pipeline uses **static concurrency** which creates a performance vs reliability tradeoff:

- **Low concurrency (current: 5)**: Safe but SLOW
  - 23 repos √ó 52 weeks of data = **~10-15 hours** for full ingestion
  - Single slow repo blocks entire pipeline
  - Underutilizes available API quota (5,000 requests/hour)

- **High concurrency**: Fast but RISKY
  - Hits secondary rate limits frequently
  - Forces pipeline to wait 15+ minutes
  - Wastes time with retry backoff cycles

### Real-World Impact

**Example from M3-org fork** (14 Optimism repositories):
- **Static concurrency=5**: 6-8 hours for full historical ingestion
- **With adaptive concurrency**: 2-3 hours (60% faster)
- **Rate limit hits**: Reduced from 10-15 to 2-3 per run

**Projected for 23 elizaOS repositories:**
- **Current static approach**: 10-15 hours
- **With adaptive concurrency**: ~4-6 hours (60-70% faster)

### Why Static Concurrency Fails

1. **API health varies** - Morning vs evening, weekday vs weekend
2. **Repository sizes differ** - Small repos finish fast, large repos take hours
3. **Rate limit recovery** - After hitting limit, pipeline should slow down temporarily
4. **Unnecessary conservatism** - Static concurrency=5 is safe but wastes quota

---

## Solution: Adaptive Concurrency Management

### Core Concept

**Dynamically adjust concurrent operations (3-8) based on rate limit health:**

- **Start conservative**: 3 concurrent operations
- **Increase on success**: +1 concurrency every 2 minutes without rate limits
- **Decrease on rate limit**: Halve concurrency immediately
- **Track health**: Remember last rate limit for 5 minutes

### Performance Benchmarks

**Test Setup**: M3-org/op-hiscores fork with 14 ethereum-optimism repos

| Metric | Static (5) | Adaptive (3-8) | Improvement |
|--------|-----------|----------------|-------------|
| **Total duration** | 6h 45min | 2h 50min | **58% faster** |
| **Rate limit hits** | 12 | 2 | **83% fewer** |
| **Avg concurrency** | 5 | 5.8 | +16% |
| **Recovery time** | 3h 20min | 45min | **77% faster** |

---

## Implementation Components

### 1. Adaptive Concurrency Manager (~110 lines)
```typescript
class AdaptiveConcurrencyManager {
  currentLevel: 3-8 (starts at 3)
  reduceOnSecondaryLimit() ‚Üí currentLevel / 2
  increaseOnSuccess() ‚Üí currentLevel + 1 (if no rate limit in 2min)
  shouldReduceLoad() ‚Üí true if rate limited in last 5min
}
```

### 2. Rate Limit Type Detection (~50 lines)
- Distinguishes **primary** vs **secondary** rate limits
- Different strategies for each type
- Primary: Wait until reset (1hr)
- Secondary: Reduce load + backoff (15min)

### 3. Adaptive Pipeline Integration (~60 lines)
```typescript
mapStep(operation, {
  adaptiveConcurrency: true,  // Enable dynamic adjustment
  defaultConcurrency: 5       // Fallback
})
```

### 4. API Cost Estimation (~75 lines)
- Shows estimated duration BEFORE execution
- `--estimate-only` flag for dry-run
- Risk assessment (LOW/MEDIUM/HIGH)

### 5. Graceful Shutdown (~30 lines)
- First Ctrl+C: Complete current operation, preserve adaptive state
- Second Ctrl+C: Force exit
- Better for long-running multi-hour ingestions

**Total**: ~348 lines across 4 files

---

## Production Testing

- **Fork**: https://github.com/M3-org/op-hiscores
- **Deployment**: https://m3-org.github.io/op-hiscores/
- **Dataset**: 14 repos, 18,000+ PRs, 4,800+ issues
- **Duration**: 6+ months in production
- **Commit**: `309c37c` - feat: Enhance pipeline with adaptive rate limiting

---

## Trade-offs

### Pros
‚úÖ **60-70% faster** for multi-repo ingestion
‚úÖ **75% fewer rate limit hits**
‚úÖ **Self-tuning** - No manual configuration needed
‚úÖ **Production-tested** - 14 repos, 18K+ PRs successfully processed
‚úÖ **Backward compatible** - Opt-in via `adaptiveConcurrency: true`

### Cons
‚ö†Ô∏è **Complexity** - 348 lines vs current static approach
‚ö†Ô∏è **Tuning** - Thresholds (3-8, 2min, 5min) may not be optimal for all workloads
‚ö†Ô∏è **Debugging** - Dynamic behavior is harder to reason about

---

## Value Proposition

For projects tracking **10+ repositories** (like this project with 23 repos), the difference between **15 hours and 4-6 hours** for full ingestion is substantial.

The self-tuning nature means:
- No manual configuration needed
- Automatically finds optimal concurrency
- Scales better as more repos are added
- Reduces developer waiting time by 6-10 hours per full ingestion

---

## Next Steps

If this enhancement aligns with the project's goals, I'm happy to:
1. Submit a PR with the full implementation
2. Provide additional benchmarks or testing
3. Adjust parameters based on your specific workload
4. Start with a subset (e.g., just rate limit type detection) if preferred

The implementation is production-ready and has been thoroughly tested with larger datasets than currently tracked by this project.

---

**Question for maintainers**: Is the ~60% performance improvement worth the additional complexity? Would you prefer the full enhancement or a smaller subset (e.g., just rate limit parsing)?

topIssues.title: feat: Upgrade leaderboard search to fuzzy matching
topIssues.author: madjin
topIssues.body:
## Summary

The current leaderboard search uses simple string matching (`.toLowerCase().includes()`), which requires exact substring matches. Upgrading to fuzzy search would improve user experience.

## Current Implementation

```typescript
// src/components/leaderboard.tsx:141
user.username.toLowerCase().includes(searchTerm.toLowerCase())
```

This requires exact matches - searching "shwa" won't find "shaw".

## Proposed Enhancement

Use `fuzzysort` (already in package.json but unused) for typo-tolerant matching:

```typescript
import fuzzysort from 'fuzzysort';

// Instead of exact matching:
const filteredUsers = fuzzysort.go(searchTerm, users, { key: 'username' })
  .map(result => result.obj);
```

## Benefits

- **Typo tolerance**: "shwa" ‚Üí finds "shaw"
- **Partial matching**: "wtfis" ‚Üí finds "wtfisagi0"  
- **Ranked results**: Best matches appear first
- **Fast**: Optimized for real-time filtering

## Context

- `fuzzysort` was added in commit `4fe3c624` (2025-01-21) during SQLite implementation
- Search UI was added in PR #92 but used simple matching
- Package is already installed, just needs to be imported and used

## Related

- See #173 for dependency audit (lists `fuzzysort` as currently unused)

topPRs.title: feat: make all fork-specific values configurable via env vars
topPRs.author: madjin
topPRs.body:
## Summary
- Replaces all hardcoded fork-specific values with environment variables
- Auto-detects BASE_PATH and SITE_URL in GitHub Actions workflow based on repository name
- Enables smooth fork syncing with upstream without conflicts

## Changes
- `next.config.js`: Use `BASE_PATH` env var instead of hardcoded `/op-hiscores`
- `AuthContext.tsx`: Use `NEXT_PUBLIC_BASE_PATH` for OAuth redirects
- `profile/page.tsx`: Use `NEXT_PUBLIC_SITE_NAME` for profile metadata
- `callAIService.ts`: Use `SITE_URL` and `SITE_NAME` with generic fallbacks
- `date-utils.ts`: Generic comment (no fork-specific text)
- `.github/workflows/deploy.yml`: Auto-detect site URL and base path from repo name

## How it works
The deploy workflow automatically detects whether this is:
- An org/user site (`*.github.io` repo) ‚Üí no base path needed
- A project site (any other repo) ‚Üí base path is `/${repo-name}`

No secrets need to be configured - values are computed at build time.

## Test plan
- [ ] Verify GitHub Actions build passes
- [ ] Verify site deploys correctly to GitHub Pages
- [ ] Verify OAuth flow works with dynamic base path

ü§ñ Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.com/claude-code)

topPRs.title: fix: add SITE_URL for RSS feed + RSS nav button
topPRs.author: madjin
topPRs.body:
## Summary
- Add `SITE_URL` environment variable to deploy workflow for RSS feed generation
- Uses fork-friendly pattern: `secrets.SITE_URL` with fallback to `https://{owner}.github.io`
- Add RSS icon button to navigation bar (desktop)
- Update default AI model to gemini-2.5-flash

## Context
The RSS feed at `/rss.xml` was returning 404 because `SITE_URL` wasn't set during the build. Since this is a static export (`output: "export"`), the route handler needs `SITE_URL` at build time to generate proper feed URLs.

The fallback pattern ensures forks can also deploy without configuring a secret - it will auto-detect the owner's github.io URL.

## Test plan
- [ ] Deploy workflow runs successfully
- [ ] RSS feed accessible at `/rss.xml`
- [ ] RSS button visible in navbar
- [ ] Feed URLs point to correct domain

Fixes the RSS feed 404 issue from PR #172

ü§ñ Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.com/claude-code)

topPRs.title: feat: add JSON leaderboard API endpoints
topPRs.author: standujar
topPRs.body:
# Add JSON Leaderboard API Endpoints

## Summary

This PR adds static JSON API endpoints for leaderboard data, enabling external applications, mobile apps, and third-party integrations to consume leaderboard information programmatically.

## Features

- **Three time periods**: Monthly, weekly, and lifetime leaderboards
- **Comprehensive scoring**: Includes total score plus breakdown by contribution type (PR, issue, review, comment)
- **Wallet addresses**: Includes Solana and Ethereum wallet addresses from GitHub profiles
- **Calendar-based periods**: 
  - Weekly: Sunday to today
  - Monthly: 1st of month to today
  - Lifetime: Project start date to today
- **CLI command**: `bun run pipeline export-leaderboard`
- **CI/CD integration**: Automatically generates fresh leaderboard data on every deployment
- **Full test coverage**: 9 comprehensive tests covering all scenarios

## API Endpoints

The following static JSON files will be available via GitHub Pages:

- `/data/api/leaderboard-monthly.json`
- `/data/api/leaderboard-weekly.json`
- `/data/api/leaderboard-lifetime.json`

## Response Format

```json
{
  "period": "monthly",
  "startDate": "2025-10-01",
  "endDate": "2025-10-23",
  "generatedAt": "2025-10-23T11:12:25.933Z",
  "totalUsers": 150,
  "leaderboard": [
    {
      "rank": 1,
      "username": "contributor1",
      "avatarUrl": "https://avatars.githubusercontent.com/...",
      "score": 1234.5,
      "prScore": 800.0,
      "issueScore": 200.0,
      "reviewScore": 150.5,
      "commentScore": 84.0,
      "wallets": {
        "solana": "9xQeWvG816bUx9EPjHmaT23yvVM2ZWbrrpZb9PusVFin",
        "ethereum": "0x742d35Cc6634C0532925a3b844Bc9e7595f0bEb"
      }
    }
  ]
}
```

## Use Cases
- Mobile apps: Display leaderboard data in native applications
- Discord bots: Show contributor rankings and stats
- Analytics dashboards: Track contributor engagement over time
- Reward systems: Automate token distributions based on rankings
- Third-party integrations: Enable community-built tools and services

## Testing
All tests pass successfully:
- bun test src/lib/pipelines/export/exportLeaderboardAPI.test.ts

topPRs.title: feat: add RSS feed endpoint
topPRs.author: madjin
topPRs.body:
## Summary
Adds `/rss.xml` endpoint that serves an RSS 2.0 feed of contributor summaries.

## Features
- 30 daily summaries
- 4 weekly summaries  
- 1 monthly summary
- Strips markdown for clean descriptions
- Proper XML escaping
- Static generation with hourly revalidation
- Uses `SITE_URL` env var for links (no hardcoded defaults)

## Usage
Subscribe to `https://your-site.com/rss.xml` in any RSS reader to get notified of new contributor summaries.

## Files Added
- `src/app/rss.xml/route.ts` - RSS feed route handler

topPRs.title: feat: add static JSON API for summaries
topPRs.author: madjin
topPRs.body:
## Summary

Extends the static JSON API with summary endpoints using a "piggyback" approach - generating JSON alongside markdown during summarization.

### Changes

- **Simplified Leaderboard API**: Removed unnecessary pagination fields (static files don't support URL params)
- **Extended fsHelpers**: Added `sha256`, path helpers, `writeJSONWithLatest`, `updateSummaryIndex`, and API types
- **Overall Summaries**: Now export JSON alongside markdown with `latest.json` and `index.json`
- **Repository Summaries**: Same JSON export for daily/weekly/monthly repo summaries
- **Contributor Summaries**: Added both markdown (was missing!) and JSON export
- **New CLI Command**: `export-summaries` for backfilling JSON from existing DB data
- **Documentation**: Comprehensive API docs in README

### API Structure

```
/data/api/
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ leaderboard-monthly.json
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ leaderboard-weekly.json
‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ leaderboard-lifetime.json
‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ summaries/
    ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ overall/{interval}/{date}.json, latest.json, index.json
    ‚îú‚îÄ‚îÄ repos/{owner}_{repo}/{interval}/{date}.json, latest.json, index.json
    ‚îî‚îÄ‚îÄ contributors/{username}/{interval}/{date}.json, latest.json, index.json
```

### Response Features

- `contentHash` (sha256) for cache validation
- `sourceLastUpdated` for tracking freshness
- `latest.json` pointers for easy access to most recent summary
- `index.json` for listing all available summaries per interval

## Test plan

- [ ] Run `bun run check` - passes lint and type checks
- [ ] Run `bun run pipeline summarize -t overall --days 1` - generates JSON alongside markdown
- [ ] Run `bun run pipeline export-summaries --dry-run` - shows what would be exported
- [ ] Verify JSON structure matches documented schema

ü§ñ Generated with [Claude Code](https://claude.com/claude-code)

<!-- This is an auto-generated comment: release notes by coderabbit.ai -->

## Summary by CodeRabbit

* **Documentation**
  * Added comprehensive API documentation for Leaderboard and Summary endpoints, including request/response schemas and export instructions.

* **New Features**
  * Added new `export-summaries` CLI command to export summaries in JSON API format with configurable types, intervals, and dry-run mode support.
  * Summary data now exported in both Markdown and JSON API formats with versioned artifacts and latest-link pointers.

* **Changes**
  * Leaderboard API responses simplified by removing pagination metadata.

<sub>‚úèÔ∏è Tip: You can customize this high-level summary in your review settings.</sub>

topContributors.summary: standujar: This month, standujar made substantial contributions across the `elizaos` ecosystem, focusing on core system stability, refactoring, and introducing new capabilities. They implemented a new Unified API for serverless Node.js environments (elizaos/eliza#6201) and delivered several complex fixes, most notably optimizing the pre-1.6.5 migration and RLS handling in the SQL plugin (elizaos/eliza#6215), which involved over 28k lines of changes. In addition to merging seven pull requests, they have eight open PRs that introduce significant new features like JWT authentication and widespread streaming support. Their work was distributed across bug fixes, feature development, and refactoring, with a strong emphasis on code and test files.

madjin: Focused on enhancing core functionality and maintaining project dependencies this month, merging three pull requests in the `elizaos/elizaos.github.io` repository. They implemented and fixed a new RSS feed feature (#172, #175) and also managed a substantial dependency update by upgrading the AI SDKs in a large PR (#170) with over 3300 new lines. Their work was a mix of bug fixes, feature implementation, and significant maintenance, touching both code and configuration files.

wtfsayo: Focused on client-side fixes and plugin migrations this month, merging two pull requests in the elizaos/eliza repository. They improved the user experience by fixing markdown content spacing (#6197) and migrated the SQL plugin to the new messageService API (#6202). Additionally, they have begun work on a new core feature for parallel action execution (#6209), with their overall contributions reflecting a primary focus on bug fixes and refactoring.

ChristopherTrimboli: Focused on core feature development and dependency management, introducing ElizaOS Cloud as the default AI provider in the CLI (elizaos/eliza#6208) and executing a significant dependency update across the ecosystem (elizaos/eliza#6210). In addition to merging these two PRs, he supported the team by providing 4 code reviews. His work primarily involved modifications to configuration and test files, reflecting a focus on system health and testing alongside feature work.

odilitime: Undertook a substantial amount of work this month, reflected in 25 commits across 25 files (+2146/-592 lines). While this work has not yet been merged via a pull request, their coding activity shows a focus on bugfixes and refactoring. They also contributed by creating an issue in elizaos-plugins/plugin-mysql (#1).

borisudovicic: Focused entirely on product definition and quality assurance for the elizaos/eliza repository this month. They created 41 issues, identifying a wide range of bugs, user experience enhancements, and new feature proposals. This work included documenting critical fixes like the container deployment bug (#6187) and proposing significant UX changes such as redesigning the dashboard (#6222) and consolidating navigation (#6173). All activity was concentrated on identifying and scoping improvements for the elizaos/eliza application.

0xbbjoker: This month, 0xbbjoker's work was primarily focused on bug fixes, contributing a significant volume of code changes across 68 files (+3655/-1134 lines). They merged one feature enhancement to the MCP provider (elizaos-plugins/plugin-mcp#19) and proactively opened an issue to improve the agent creator's file handling (elizaos/eliza#6245). In addition to their direct code contributions, they were an active collaborator, providing 6 code reviews for their peers.
